sn12.63:1.2.pli: “cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃ vā anuggahāya.
sn12.63:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, these four fuels maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those about to be born.
sn12.63:1.2.comm: On the four fuels see SN 12.11. Here the Buddha drives home the suffering of dependency with a series of unforgettable similes.

sn12.63:1.4.pli: Kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṃ catutthaṃ.
sn12.63:1.4.eng: Edible food, whether solid or subtle; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

sn12.63:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃ vā anuggahāya.
sn12.63:1.5.eng: These are the four fuels that maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those about to be born.

sn12.63:2.1.eng: And how should you regard edible food?

sn12.63:2.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dve jāyampatikā parittaṃ sambalaṃ ādāya kantāramaggaṃ paṭipajjeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:2.2.eng: Suppose a couple who were husband and wife set out to cross a desert, taking limited supplies.

sn12.63:2.3.eng: They had an only child, dear and beloved.

sn12.63:2.4.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ jāyampatikānaṃ kantāragatānaṃ yā parittā sambalamattā, sā parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya.
sn12.63:2.4.eng: As the couple were crossing the desert their limited quantity of supplies would run out,

sn12.63:2.5.eng: and they’d still have the rest of the desert to cross.

sn12.63:2.6.pli: Atha kho tesaṃ, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ jāyampatikānaṃ evamassa:
sn12.63:2.6.eng: Then it would occur to that couple:

sn12.63:2.7.pli: ‘amhākaṃ kho yā parittā sambalamattā sā parikkhīṇā pariyādiṇṇā.
sn12.63:2.7.eng: ‘Our limited quantity of supplies has run out,

sn12.63:2.8.eng: and we still have the rest of the desert to cross.

sn12.63:2.9.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ imaṃ ekaputtakaṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ vadhitvā vallūrañca soṇḍikañca karitvā puttamaṃsāni khādantā evaṃ taṃ kantārāvasesaṃ nitthareyyāma, mā sabbeva tayo vinassimhā’ti.
sn12.63:2.9.eng: Why don’t we kill our only child, so dear and beloved, and prepare dried and spiced meat? Then we can make it across the desert by eating our child’s flesh. Let not all three perish.’
sn12.63:2.9.comm: In the Mahābhārata, Bhīṣma forcefully condemned meat eating, saying, “The meat of other animals is like the flesh of one’s child” (13.115.010c; cf. 13.148.017c). Some, however, believed a child’s flesh had magic potency (Kathāsaritsāgara 29d).

sn12.63:2.10.pli: Atha kho te, bhikkhave, dve jāyampatikā taṃ ekaputtakaṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ vadhitvā vallūrañca soṇḍikañca karitvā puttamaṃsāni khādantā evaṃ taṃ kantārāvasesaṃ nitthareyyuṃ.
sn12.63:2.10.eng: Then that couple would kill their only child, so dear and beloved, and prepare dried and spiced meat. They’d make it across the desert by eating their child’s flesh.

sn12.63:2.11.pli: Te puttamaṃsāni ceva khādeyyuṃ, ure ca paṭipiseyyuṃ:
sn12.63:2.11.eng: And as they’d eat their child’s flesh, they’d beat their breasts and cry:

sn12.63:2.12.eng: ‘Where are you, our only child? Where are you, our only child?’

sn12.63:3.2.pli: api nu te davāya vā āhāraṃ āhāreyyuṃ, madāya vā āhāraṃ āhāreyyuṃ, maṇḍanāya vā āhāraṃ āhāreyyuṃ, vibhūsanāya vā āhāraṃ āhāreyyun”ti?
sn12.63:3.2.eng: Would they eat that food for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration?”

sn12.63:3.4.pli: “Nanu te, bhikkhave, yāvadeva kantārassa nittharaṇatthāya āhāraṃ āhāreyyun”ti?
sn12.63:3.4.eng: “Wouldn’t they eat that food just so they could make it across the desert?”

sn12.63:3.6.pli: “‘Evameva khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, kabaḷīkāro āhāro daṭṭhabbo’ti vadāmi.
sn12.63:3.6.eng: “I say that this is how you should regard edible food.

sn12.63:3.7.pli: Kabaḷīkāre, bhikkhave, āhāre pariññāte pañca kāmaguṇiko rāgo pariññāto hoti.
sn12.63:3.7.eng: When edible food is completely understood, desire for the five kinds of sensual stimulation is completely understood.

sn12.63:3.8.pli: Pañca kāmaguṇike rāge pariññāte natthi taṃ saṃyojanaṃ yena saṃyojanena saṃyutto ariyasāvako puna imaṃ lokaṃ āgaccheyya.
sn12.63:3.8.eng: When desire for the five kinds of sensual stimulation is completely understood, a noble disciple is bound by no fetter that might return them again to this world.
sn12.63:3.8.comm: This reflection goes as far as non-return, because the focus is on the elimination of sense desire.

sn12.63:4.1.eng: And how should you regard contact as fuel?

sn12.63:4.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāvī niccammā kuṭṭañce nissāya tiṭṭheyya. Ye kuṭṭanissitā pāṇā te naṃ khādeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:4.2.eng: Suppose there was a flayed cow. If she stands by a wall, the creatures on the wall bite her.
sn12.63:4.2.comm: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.2.13–17 explains that the cow was once naked, so the gods flayed man and clothed the cow with it. Now a man bleeds when cut even by grass, whereas a cow endures rain and cold and heat.

sn12.63:4.3.pli: Rukkhañce nissāya tiṭṭheyya, ye rukkhanissitā pāṇā te naṃ khādeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:4.3.eng: If she stands under a tree, the creatures in the tree bite her.

sn12.63:4.4.pli: Udakañce nissāya tiṭṭheyya, ye udakanissitā pāṇā te naṃ khādeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:4.4.eng: If she stands in some water, the creatures in the water bite her.

sn12.63:4.5.pli: Ākāsañce nissāya tiṭṭheyya, ye ākāsanissitā pāṇā te naṃ khādeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:4.5.eng: If she stands in the open, the creatures in the open bite her.

sn12.63:4.6.pli: Yaṃ yadeva hi sā, bhikkhave, gāvī niccammā nissāya tiṭṭheyya, ye tannissitā pāṇā te naṃ khādeyyuṃ.
sn12.63:4.6.eng: Wherever that flayed cow stands, the creatures there would bite her.

sn12.63:4.7.eng: I say that this is how you should regard contact as fuel.

sn12.63:4.8.pli: Phasse, bhikkhave, āhāre pariññāte tisso vedanā pariññātā honti.
sn12.63:4.8.eng: When contact as fuel is completely understood, the three feelings are completely understood.

sn12.63:4.9.pli: Tīsu vedanāsu pariññātāsu ariyasāvakassa natthi kiñci uttarikaraṇīyanti vadāmi.
sn12.63:4.9.eng: When the three feelings are completely understood, a noble disciple has nothing further to do, I say.

sn12.63:5.1.eng: And how should you regard mental intention as fuel?

sn12.63:5.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, aṅgārakāsu sādhikaporisā puṇṇā aṅgārānaṃ vītaccikānaṃ vītadhūmānaṃ.
sn12.63:5.2.eng: Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, filled with glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
sn12.63:5.2.comm: Such pits are frequently mentioned in the suttas and must have been a common sight. Since fired bricks were not regularly produced, perhaps they were used for metals or pottery, although kilns are also mentioned. Falling in one is an apt simile for the pains of hell (AN 7.66:8.3, SN 12.51:12.1).

sn12.63:5.3.pli: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
sn12.63:5.3.eng: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.

sn12.63:5.4.pli: Tamenaṃ dve balavanto purisā nānābāhāsu gahetvā taṃ aṅgārakāsuṃ upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.
sn12.63:5.4.eng: Two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.

sn12.63:5.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa ārakāvassa cetanā ārakā patthanā ārakā paṇidhi.
sn12.63:5.5.eng: Then that person’s intention, aim, and wish would be to get far away.

sn12.63:5.8.pli: ‘imañcāhaṃ aṅgārakāsuṃ papatissāmi, tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigacchāmi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhan’ti.
sn12.63:5.8.eng: ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that will result in my death or deadly pain.’

sn12.63:5.9.eng: I say that this is how you should regard mental intention as fuel.

sn12.63:5.10.pli: Manosañcetanāya, bhikkhave, āhāre pariññāte tisso taṇhā pariññātā honti.
sn12.63:5.10.eng: When mental intention as fuel is completely understood, the three cravings are completely understood.

sn12.63:5.11.pli: Tīsu taṇhāsu pariññātāsu ariyasāvakassa natthi kiñci uttarikaraṇīyanti vadāmi.
sn12.63:5.11.eng: When the three cravings are completely understood, a noble disciple has nothing further to do, I say.

sn12.63:6.1.eng: And how should you regard consciousness as fuel?

sn12.63:6.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā rañño dasseyyuṃ:
sn12.63:6.2.eng: Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to the king, saying:

sn12.63:6.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, deva, coro āgucārī, imassa yaṃ icchasi taṃ daṇḍaṃ paṇehī’ti.
sn12.63:6.3.eng: ‘Your Majesty, this is a bandit, a criminal. Punish him as you will.’

sn12.63:6.5.pli: ‘gacchatha, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ pubbaṇhasamayaṃ sattisatena hanathā’ti.
sn12.63:6.5.eng: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the morning with a hundred spears!’

sn12.63:6.6.eng: The king’s men did as they were told.

sn12.63:6.7.eng: Then at midday the king would say:

sn12.63:6.11.pli: ‘gacchatha, bho, taṃ purisaṃ majjhanhikasamayaṃ sattisatena hanathā’ti.
sn12.63:6.11.eng: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the middle of the day with a hundred spears!’

sn12.63:6.12.eng: The king’s men did as they were told.

sn12.63:6.13.eng: Then late in the afternoon the king would say:

sn12.63:6.17.pli: ‘gacchatha, bho, taṃ purisaṃ sāyanhasamayaṃ sattisatena hanathā’ti.
sn12.63:6.17.eng: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the late afternoon with a hundred spears!’

sn12.63:6.18.eng: The king’s men did as they were told.

sn12.63:6.20.pli: api nu so puriso divasaṃ tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvediyethā”ti?
sn12.63:6.20.eng: Would that man experience pain and distress from being struck with three hundred spears a day?”

sn12.63:6.21.pli: “Ekissāpi, bhante, sattiyā haññamāno tatonidānaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ paṭisaṃvediyetha;
sn12.63:6.21.eng: “Sir, that man would experience pain and distress from being struck with one spear,

sn12.63:6.22.pli: ko pana vādo tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno”ti.

sn12.63:6.23.eng: “I say that this is how you should regard consciousness as fuel.
sn12.63:6.23.comm: This too is in reference to the sufferings undergone by consciousness in transmigration, especially in the hells (MN 129:8.2, SN 56.35).

sn12.63:6.24.pli: Viññāṇe, bhikkhave, āhāre pariññāte nāmarūpaṃ pariññātaṃ hoti, nāmarūpe pariññāte ariyasāvakassa natthi kiñci uttarikaraṇīyanti vadāmī”ti.
sn12.63:6.24.eng: When consciousness as fuel is completely understood, name and form is completely understood. When name and form are completely understood, a noble disciple has nothing further to do, I say.”

sn12.64:1.2.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃ vā anuggahāya.
sn12.64:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, these four fuels maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those about to be born.

sn12.64:1.4.pli: Kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṃ catutthaṃ.
sn12.64:1.4.eng: Edible food, whether solid or subtle; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

sn12.64:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro āhārā bhūtānaṃ vā sattānaṃ ṭhitiyā sambhavesīnaṃ vā anuggahāya.
sn12.64:1.5.eng: These are the four fuels that maintain sentient beings that have been born and help those about to be born.

sn12.64:2.1.pli: Kabaḷīkāre ce, bhikkhave, āhāre atthi rāgo atthi nandī atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:2.1.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for edible food, consciousness becomes established there and grows.
sn12.64:2.1.comm: Consciousness is organic, established or planted like a seed, for which see also SN 22.54, AN 3.76], [AN 3.77.

sn12.64:2.2.pli: Yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ, atthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:2.2.eng: Where consciousness is established and grows, name and form are conceived.

sn12.64:2.3.pli: Yattha atthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, atthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:2.3.eng: Where name and form are conceived, there is the growth of choices.
sn12.64:2.3.comm: As an individual matures, they develop the capacity to make responsible moral decisions.

sn12.64:2.4.pli: Yattha atthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, atthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:2.4.eng: Where choices grow, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.
sn12.64:2.4.comm: Here choices in this life directly beget rebirth, which is normally stated as “consciousness”.

sn12.64:2.5.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, atthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:2.5.eng: Where there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:2.6.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, sasokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, sadaraṃ saupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:2.6.eng: Where there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say this is full of sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:3.1.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for contact as fuel …

sn12.64:3.2.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for mental intention as fuel …

sn12.64:3.3.pli: viññāṇe ce, bhikkhave, āhāre atthi rāgo atthi nandī atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:3.3.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for consciousness as fuel, consciousness becomes established there and grows.

sn12.64:3.4.pli: Yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ, atthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:3.4.eng: Where consciousness is established and grows, name and form are conceived.

sn12.64:3.5.pli: Yattha atthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, atthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:3.5.eng: Where name and form are conceived, there is the growth of choices.

sn12.64:3.6.pli: Yattha atthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, atthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:3.6.eng: Where choices grow, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:3.7.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, atthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:3.7.eng: Where there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:3.8.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, sasokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, sadaraṃ saupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:3.8.eng: Where there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say this is full of sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, rajako vā cittakārako vā sati rajanāya vā lākhāya vā haliddiyā vā nīliyā vā mañjiṭṭhāya vā suparimaṭṭhe vā phalake bhittiyā vā dussapaṭṭe vā itthirūpaṃ vā purisarūpaṃ vā abhinimmineyya sabbaṅgapaccaṅgaṃ;
sn12.64:4.1.eng: Suppose an artist or painter had some dye, red lac, turmeric, indigo, or rose madder. And on a polished plank or a wall or a canvas they’d create the form of a woman or a man, whole in its major and minor limbs.

sn12.64:4.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, kabaḷīkāre ce āhāre atthi rāgo atthi nandī atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:4.2.eng: In the same way, if there is desire, relishing, and craving for edible food, consciousness becomes established there and grows.

sn12.64:4.3.pli: Yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ, atthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:4.3.eng: Where consciousness is established and grows, name and form are conceived.

sn12.64:4.4.pli: Yattha atthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, atthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:4.4.eng: Where name and form are conceived, there is the growth of choices.

sn12.64:4.5.pli: Yattha atthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, atthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:4.5.eng: Where choices grow, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:4.6.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, atthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:4.6.eng: Where there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:4.7.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, sasokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, sadaraṃ saupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:4.7.eng: Where there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say this is full of sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:5.1.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for contact as fuel …

sn12.64:5.2.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for mental intention as fuel …

sn12.64:5.3.pli: viññāṇe ce, bhikkhave, āhāre atthi rāgo atthi nandī atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:5.3.eng: If there is desire, relishing, and craving for consciousness as fuel, consciousness becomes established there and grows.

sn12.64:5.4.pli: Yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ virūḷhaṃ, atthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:5.4.eng: Where consciousness is established and grows, name and form are conceived.

sn12.64:5.5.pli: Yattha atthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, atthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:5.5.eng: Where name and form are conceived, there is the growth of choices.

sn12.64:5.6.pli: Yattha atthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, atthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:5.6.eng: Where choices grow, there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:5.7.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, atthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:5.7.eng: Where there is regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:5.8.pli: Yattha atthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, sasokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, sadaraṃ saupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:5.8.eng: Where there is rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say this is full of sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:6.1.pli: Kabaḷīkāre ce, bhikkhave, āhāre natthi rāgo natthi nandī natthi taṇhā, appatiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:6.1.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for edible food, consciousness does not become established there and doesn’t grow.

sn12.64:6.2.pli: Yattha appatiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ, natthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:6.2.eng: Where consciousness is not established and doesn’t grow, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.64:6.3.pli: Yattha natthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, natthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:6.3.eng: Where name and form are not conceived, there is no growth of choices.

sn12.64:6.4.pli: Yattha natthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, natthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:6.4.eng: Where choices don’t grow, there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:6.5.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, natthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:6.5.eng: Where there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:6.6.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, asokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, adaraṃ anupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:6.6.eng: Where there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say there’s no sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:7.1.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for contact as fuel …

sn12.64:7.2.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for mental intention as fuel …

sn12.64:7.3.pli: viññāṇe ce, bhikkhave, āhāre natthi rāgo natthi nandī natthi taṇhā, appatiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:7.3.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for consciousness as fuel, consciousness doesn’t become established there and doesn’t grow.

sn12.64:7.4.pli: Yattha appatiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ, natthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:7.4.eng: Where consciousness is not established and doesn’t grow, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.64:7.5.pli: Yattha natthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, natthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:7.5.eng: Where name and form are not conceived, there is no growth of choices.

sn12.64:7.6.pli: Yattha natthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, natthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:7.6.eng: Where choices don’t grow, there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:7.7.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, natthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:7.7.eng: Where there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:7.8.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ, asokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, adaraṃ anupāyāsanti vadāmi.
sn12.64:7.8.eng: Where there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say there’s no sorrow, anguish, and distress.

sn12.64:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgāraṃ vā kūṭāgārasālaṃ vā uttarāya vā dakkhiṇāya vā pācīnāya vā vātapānā sūriye uggacchante vātapānena rasmi pavisitvā kvāssa patiṭṭhitā”ti?
sn12.64:8.1.eng: Suppose there was a bungalow or a hall with a peaked roof, with windows on the northern, southern, or eastern side. When the sun rises and a ray of light enters through a window, where would it land?”

sn12.64:8.3.pli: “Pacchimā ce, bhikkhave, bhitti nāssa kvāssa patiṭṭhitā”ti?
sn12.64:8.3.eng: “If there was no western wall, where would it land?”

sn12.64:8.5.eng: “If there was no ground, where would it land?”

sn12.64:8.7.eng: “If there was no water, where would it land?”

sn12.64:8.8.comm: If a beam of light does not land anywhere, it cannot perform its key function, namely to illuminate. Likewise, if consciousness is not established in craving, it cannot perform its key function of perpetuating the cycle of rebirth.

sn12.64:8.9.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, kabaḷīkāre ce āhāre natthi rāgo natthi nandī natthi taṇhā …pe….
sn12.64:8.9.eng: “In the same way, if there is no desire, relishing, and craving for edible food, consciousness does not become established there and doesn’t grow. …

sn12.64:9.1.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for contact as fuel …

sn12.64:9.2.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for mental intention as fuel …

sn12.64:9.3.pli: viññāṇe ce, bhikkhave, āhāre natthi rāgo natthi nandī natthi taṇhā, appatiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ.
sn12.64:9.3.eng: If there is no desire, relishing, and craving for consciousness as fuel, consciousness doesn’t become established there and doesn’t grow.

sn12.64:9.4.pli: Yattha appatiṭṭhitaṃ viññāṇaṃ avirūḷhaṃ, natthi tattha nāmarūpassa avakkanti.
sn12.64:9.4.eng: Where consciousness is not established and doesn’t grow, name and form are not conceived.

sn12.64:9.5.pli: Yattha natthi nāmarūpassa avakkanti, natthi tattha saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi.
sn12.64:9.5.eng: Where name and form are not conceived, there is no growth of choices.

sn12.64:9.6.pli: Yattha natthi saṅkhārānaṃ vuddhi, natthi tattha āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti.
sn12.64:9.6.eng: Where choices don’t grow, there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future.

sn12.64:9.7.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbatti, natthi tattha āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ.
sn12.64:9.7.eng: Where there is no regeneration into a new state of existence in the future, there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future.

sn12.64:9.8.pli: Yattha natthi āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇaṃ asokaṃ taṃ, bhikkhave, adaraṃ anupāyāsanti vadāmī”ti.
sn12.64:9.8.eng: Where there is no rebirth, old age, and death in the future, I say there’s no sorrow, anguish, and distress.”
